Novel nano-conjugate materials for effective arsenic(V) and phosphate
capturing in aqueous media

Research highlights:
 Novel nano-conjugate material was effective for arsenic(V) and phosphate capturing.  The ammonium molybdate ligand was linked to the Uio-66 carrier to ligand.  The nano-conjugate material was selective over a wide range of cations and anions.  The material could capture the arsenic(V) and phosphate in industrial waters.
Graphical Abstract
A B S T R A C T
In this study, the ligand functionalized nano-conjugate material was developed for the sensitive and selective detection and removal of toxic arsenic(V) and phosphate ions in aqueous media. The nano-conjugate material was fabricated based on the use of metalorganic frameworks with exhibited of high surface area, pore morphology, and tuneable shape. The newly design nano-conjugate material was exhibited the naked eye monitoring of the ultra-trace arsenic(V) and phosphate in a simple, fast, cost-effective and easy-to-use approach. The data clarified that the arsenic(V) and phosphate adsorption process were found to be relatively fast. The adsorption isotherms of arsenic(V) and phosphate from aqueous solutions to the nano-conjugate material were measured, and the results showed that the Langmuir isotherm was found to be the best represent the measured adsorption data. The maximum adsorption capacity was 82.40 and 70.47 mg/g for arsenic(V) and phosphate, respectively. The arsenic(V) and phosphate detection and removal were not affected in the presence of co-existing divers ions. Calibration curves were demonstrated by using UV-Vis spectrophotometric and digital image-based colorimetric analysis. The linear correlation obtained from the two methods, and the detection limit of arsenic(V) and phosphate were 0.15 and 0.13 μg/L, respectively. In addition, the nano-conjugate material was regenerated by 0.20 M NaOH treatment the arsenic(V) and phosphate detection or removal efficiency was retained almost as that of the original performance. In addition, the nano-conjugate material was applied to the determination and removal of arsenic(V) and phosphate in natural and industrial water samples. Therefore, the newly developed nanomaterial has potentiality for efficient detection and removal of arsenic(V) and phosphate in the real wastewater samples.
Keywords: Nano-conjugate materials; Arsenic(V) and phosphate; Monitoring and removal; Sensitivity and selectivity; Reuses.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Phosphorus, in the form of phosphate, is an essential macronutrient in freshwater that
influences the organisms’ growth as a key component of several biomolecules such as phospholipids and adenosine triphosphate (ATP) [1]. However, high phosphate concentrations in aquatic systems are the phenomenon of eutrophication, which causes algal bloom formation. Phosphate has been used in large quantities in detergents, fertilizers and sugar industries. Because of the biological and environmental significance of phosphate ions, selective and sensitive recognitions of phosphates are important [2].
Arsenic (As) is broadly distributed in earth crust and soils. This is noted that the As is
released into the environment through the weathering and erosion of sulphide minerals. Therefore, the sulphide minerals can form soils with very high concentrations of arsenic, and can dissolve in water with formation of arsenite and arsenate. In addition, the industry and agriculture can also contribute to the contamination of water with arsenic. The As is toxic and long-term exposure to As contaminated water can cause hyperkeratosis, diarrhea, kidney and nervous system disorders, and skin cancer [3-5].
Many analytical methods and techniques have been developed for the accurate
monitoring and removal of phosphate [6-9]. The most common methods for measuring of phosphate ion are titrometry, complexogravimetry, colorimetry, atomic absorption spectroscopy, flow injection analysis, HPLC, ion-exclusion chromatography coupled with UV-detection and spectrophotometry methods [10-17]. These techniques are unsuitable due to the lack the combination of sensitivity, portability, and low cost for remote sensing of As. Moreover, these are exhibited expensive apparatus, costly maintenance, multi-step processes, and complicated sample preparation, including pre-concentration procedures.
Several spectrophotometric methods for the determination of arsenic have been reported based on a molybdenum blue complex [18,19], diethyldithiocarbamate complex [20,21] and
molybdate–rhodamine B complex [22]. Although the detection limits of these methods are low enough to measure 0.01 mg/L of arsenic, however; there is a room to improve the methods from the stand point of easy-to-use in the developing countries. Molybdenum is known to form so called hetero poly acids with arsenic(V) to give an intense blue color under the reductive conditions. Since the development of this blue color is very stable and corresponds to the concentration of arsenic(V) as it is used for the determination of arsenic [18,19]. In this study, we have adapted the solid phase detection by fabricating the solid optical material for arsenic detection.
Recently, the need for real-time, compact, and inexpensive chemical detectors has
become more pressing. nanomaterials offer several advantages such as selectivity, sensitivity, low detection limit and fast response time. Optical detectors allow in situ real-time visual detections without using sophisticated instruments. Therefore, many studies have reported the development of colorimetric systems for sensing of diverse metal ions [23-31].
Over the last few decades, the study of porous materials has achieved
significant advances considering the number of different materials and the variety of structures and compositions. Most of these achievements are based on a recent class of nanostructured materials known as metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) that are obtained by the self-assembly between metal ions or clusters and polytopic rigid organic linkers [32]. Due to the high directionality and defined geometry of metal complexes and the rigidity of the organic linkers used, in general, their combination forms organized tri-dimensional arrays with high asymmetric crystal structures. In addition, the materials with high surface area and narrow pore size distribution are widely explored in applications such as heterogeneous catalysis and gas separation and storage [33,34].
Digital image-based analysis is based on the analysis of Red Green Blue (RGB) primary
color data obtained from digital images [35]. The images are generated by a digital camera
based on the use of charge-coupled devices [35,36], where the reflected light from the colored products of a colorimetric test would pass through and produced the three different states such as red, green, and blue. After scaling and adjustment, the data were obtained as individual RGB values, and the final color was composed of the additive data of the three RGB filters. Then the RGB values derived from the capture of digital images of presumptive colorimetric tests to calibrate the images on the basis concentration of illicit material. This effort provided the basis upon which semi-quantitative analysis of illicit samples containing an unknown quantity of material [37].
In the present work, a Zr-based metal-organic framework (UiO-66) was used as a carrier
for the ammonium molybdate impregnation after modification its surface by cationic surfactant. The newly designed solid nano-conjugate material was used successfully for determination of arsenic(V) and phosphate ions. The influence of various parameters was carried out systematically and the analytical performance of the novel nano-conjugate material was evaluated. Both of the spectrophotometric and digital image-based colorimetric analysis strategies were applied to the determination of both ions.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
All solutions were prepared using deionized water (LaboStar™ TWF ultrapure water
purification systems, San Diego, CA & USA), and all reagents used were of analytical grade as purchased without further purification. Before use, the glassware was kept overnight in 10% (v/v) HNO3 aqueous solution, rinsed with deionized water and dried in a dust-free environment. Dimethylformamide (DMF 99%), terephthalic acid, (BDC 98.9%), ZrCl4, KCl, CH3COONa, HCl, and CH3COOH were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Chemicals (Munich, Germany). The arsenic standard solution was BDH. N-Dodecylpyridinium chloride (DPC),
ammonium molybdate, potassium antimony(III) oxide tartrate, ethanol and ascorbic acid were obtained from Merck (Wadeville, South Africa). Buffer solutions of 0.2 M KCl-HCl and 0.1 M CH3COOH-CH3COONa were utilized to adjust the pH in the 1–6 range. 4-(2- hydroxyethyl)- 1-piperazineethanesulfonic acid (HEPES), where NaOH (0.1 M) were utilized to adjust the pH in the 7–8 range. In addition, sodium tetraborate (0.1 M) and NaOH (0.1 M) were utilized to adjust the pH in the 9–12 range.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of Metal-organic framework (UiO-66)
sections.text:
Zr-MOF (UiO-66) which was used as scaffold and synthesized accordingly as reported
elsewhere [38]; by dissolving of ZrCl4 (2.27 mmol/L) with terephthalic acid (H2BDC) (2.27 mmol/L) in N, N-Dimethylformamide (DMF) (405.38 mmol/L) at the room temperature The obtained mixture was added to a vessel, which was sealed and heated to 393 K for 24 hr. The obtained MOF was filtered and repeatedly washed with DMF then immersed in 80 mL of chloroform for 5 days to remove the excess terephthalic acid. The resulting powder was collected by filtration and dried under vacuum at 463 K for 48 h.

sections.heading: 2.3. Building blocks and fabrication of nano-conjugate materials
sections.text:
The synthesis of nano-conjugate materials is represented in Scheme 1. A positively
charged layer was built by immobilization of N-Dodecylpyridinium chloride (DPC) as a cationic detergent on the surface of UiO-66 substrate. Typically, 1.0 g of the synthesized UiO-66 was added into ethanol solution of 0.30 g DPC and stirred for 6 h. Then, the mixture was filtered off, and the precipitate was washed with ethanol to remove excess DPC. The nano-conjugate material was fabricated by stirring 1.0 g of DPC/UiO-66 with ammonium molybdate solution (0.15 gm in 50 ml water) for 4 h. The water was removed by filtration, and the resulting nano-conjugate materials was washed with deionized water to remove
excess molybdate ions and dried at 80 o C in vacuum oven. The immobilization process was repeated in order to reach the equilibrium saturation. The adsorption amount (Q, mmol/g) of the ammonium molybdate at saturation was found to be (0.2 mmol/g), and it was determined by the following equation:
Qt= (Co– Ct) V m -1
(1)
Where Qt, was the adsorbed amount at saturation time t, V is the solution volume (L), m
is the weight of UiO-66 carriers (g), Co and Ct are the initial concentration and final concentration, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.4. Arsenic(V) and phosphate sensing using UV-Vis Spectrophotometer
sections.text:
The colorimetric determination and visual detection of arsenic(V) and phosphate ions
using nano-conjugate materials were carried out by adding specific concentrations of arsenic(V) and phosphate in the presence of potassium antimony(III) oxide tartrate and ascorbic acid. 10 mg of the nano-conjugate materials was added to the mixture (a constant volume of 25 mL) and sonicated for 5 s then vortexed for 30 min. After equilibration, response time (Rt, see Table 1), in which a noticeable color change was observed in nanoconjugate materials, the solid nano-conjugate material was collected using suction with 25 mm diameter filter paper. The color of the collected sample was observed by naked-eye and UV–vis spectrometry.
2.5. Arsenic(V) and phosphate sensing using digital image-based colorimetric analysis
Scanning of the color scales was performed with a Canon D700 camera (18
megapixels 22.3 x 14.9 mm 12- bit RGB CMOS sensor) with camera length EF-S. The size of a picture with selected quality was (5184 × 3456 pixel). The pictures were in JPEG (24- bit) format and stored on a compact flash card in the camera. Determination of the
colorimetric characteristics of the obtained images and transformations of the color coordinates were performed using the Adobe Photoshop CS5 (64 Bit) on a personal laptop. In order to do this, an oval region was selected ion the middle of the image of the colored sample using the ‘‘Crop’’ tool called “Elliptical Marquee Tool” and the average color intensities of Red, Green, and Blue of each image were obtained by using the ‘‘Histogram” tool. All data were transferred to Microsoft Excel 2013 spreadsheet for subsequent data analysis using Origin Pro 9.0.0 (64 Bit) for data plotting.

sections.heading: 2.6. Instruments
sections.text:
The spectra of the nano-conjugate materials were collected using a Shimadzu UV-
2600 UV-VIS spectrophotometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the samples were measured at ambient temperature on a Bruker D2 Phaser using a flat sample holder and Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54182 Å). The N2 isotherms were measured on a Quantachrome Nova 4200e. The surface area of the samples was determined by volumetric nitrogen sorption measurements at 77 K. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) was obtained using a Zeiss Leo Supra55 microscope. The samples for FESEM observations were observed without metal coating. The concentrations of metal ions were analyzed by using a Seiko SPS1500 inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES) before and after adsorption operation.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of the nano-conjugate materials
sections.text:
Scheme 1 shows the general synthesis design of optical nano-conjugate materials based
on the building-blocks approach. The building block technique gives a long-term stability for monitoring and removal of divers metal ions [27,39]. The polarity of the UiO-66 surface was
first fine-tuned by the dense dispersion of cationic surfactant such as DPC. The successful dispersion of large amounts of DPC led to increased polarity of the surface carriers and therefore enhanced the ability to attract and adsorb the molybdate molecules ions with dense immobilization. In such immobilization of probes led to high flexibility in binding with arsenic(V) or phosphate ions even at low concentrations and thus enhancing the stability and robustness of the nano-conjugate material.
The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis was obtained for the parent UiO-66, the
charged UiO-66 after loading with DPC (Fig. 1). The prepared UiO-66 showed well-defined diffraction peaks, which are similar to typical UiO-66 structure confirming the successful preparation of pure UiO-66 [40]. It is also worth mentioning that the charged carrier DPC/UiO-66 and the nano-conjugate materials are closely similar to that of the parent UiO66 although the intensity of the diffraction peaks becomes weaker, indicating the crystal structure of UiO-66 retained unaltered after the loading of DPC and molybdate.
The field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) images of UiO-66,
DPC/UiO-66, and nano-conjugate materials are shown in Fig. 2 (A-C), respectively. The SEM images showed the morphology and the homogeneity of the particles of UiO-66. It is also showed the similarity and the retention of the structure of UiO-66 after loading of DPC and molybdate probe into the surface, which is consistent with PXRD patterns (Fig. 1).
The consequences of the N2-adsorption isotherms of the UiO-66, the charged carrier
DPC/UiO-66 and the nano-conjugate materials are depicted in Fig. 3. The N2 isotherms of all samples were exhibited a typical Type I isotherm characteristic of microporous materials according to IUPA classification. The specific surface area values were 864 m 2 g −1 for pristine UiO-66 and decreased to 678 and 580 m 2 g −1 for the charged carrier DPC/UiO-66 and the nano-conjugate materials, respectively, while the pore volume decreases from 0.465 cm 3 /g to 0.362 and 0.297 cm 3 /g for the same materials. The significant decrease in the surface
area and the pore volume of the charged carrier DPC/UiO-66 and the nano-conjugate materials compared with UiO-66 due to the inclusion of DPC and then molybdate probe molecules onto the UiO-66 surface that make some of the framework pores partially clogged and inaccessible to nitrogen molecules.

sections.heading: 3.2. Recognition of arsenic(V) and phosphate
sections.text:
It is well known that molybdenum oxides form a hetero polyacid with silicate, phosphate,
and arsenic(V). Since such a hetero polyacid gives blue color under the reductive conditions, which corresponds the target anions detection [18,19,41–43]. In the present study, the reaction was forming molybdenum blue color in the solid phase under similar conditions to those in the homogeneous system. The main factors are the pH, reagent concentration, weight of material, response time, and reaction temperature [44-46]. These parameters were strongly affected the color distribution homogeneity with intensity at very low concentrations of target ions during visual detection. In order to determine an optimum pH value for arsenic(V) and phosphate ion sensing, a wide range of various pH solutions were prepared and the change of absorbance was measured where the initial each ions concentration was 1.0 mg/L (Fig. 4A). The highest absorbance spectra and highest sensitivity were observed at pH 1.5 and 2.0 for phosphate and arsenic(V), respectively. The reagents which was also used in recognition of arsenic(V) and phosphate ions were composed of ascorbic acid and potassium antimony(III) oxide tartrate. Firstly, the potassium antimony(III) oxide tartrate concentration was fixed, and the concentration of ascorbic acid was studied (Fig. 4B). It is of note that the excess ascorbic acid (over 0.4 M for both arsenic(V) and phosphate ions) not affect the color reaction in contrast to the corresponding aqueous reaction in which the blue color diminishes at higher concentration of ascorbic acid [47].
Secondly, the potassium antimony(III) oxide tartrate was added to speed color
development at room temperature [48], the concentration of ascorbic acid was fixed at 0.4 M, and the concentration of potassium antimony(III) oxide tartrate was varied (Fig. 4C). It was recognized that the detection efficiency was increased by long-time contact between nanoconjugate materials and both of arsenic(V) and phosphate ions in the solution at room temperature. The effect of shaking time (contact time) on the adsorption of arsenic(V) and phosphate ions was studied (Fig. 4D). Although the adsorption reaction was done at room temperature, the equilibrium in color optimization due to the formation of a hetero polyacid was reached after shaking for 20 and 30 min for phosphate and arsenic(V), respectively. It was also found that the developed color was very stable and did not change during the detection procedure under optimum conditions [49].
The calibration plot of the nano-conjugate material is shown in Fig. 5. It was
represented the absorbance of 10 mg of the nano-conjugate material with various concentrations of arsenic(V) and phosphate ions at their optimum conditions. Absorption spectra were increased with increasing the each ions concentration at a wavelength of 785 nm and 800 nm for phosphate and arsenic(V), respectively. The sensitivity is summarized with procedure both of the phosphate and arsenic(V) in Table 1. The calibration curves (Fig. 6) showed a linear correlation at low concentration of phosphate and arsenic(V). This linear correlation was confirmed that the phosphate and arsenic(V) were estimated with high sensitivity over a wide range of ultra-trace concentrations. The detection (LOD) and quantification (LOQ) limits of these ions using the nano-conjugate materials were estimated according to the following equation [50] (Table 2).

Where, Sb and m are the standard deviation and the slope of the linear calibration graph (Fig. 6, insets); the constant k is equal to 3 and 10, respectively in the case of LOD and LOQ
determination. The nano-conjugate material showed high sensitivity for arsenic(V) and phosphate ions comparing with the alternative spectrophotometric method as summarized in Table 3 [51-57].

sections.heading: 3.3. Interference
sections.text:
At first, the interference was studied in the case of arsenic(V) determination. The
main competing ions are phosphate and silicate. To avoid the interaction of these ions, sample pretreatment was applied. When a sample containing 5 mg/L of phosphate was passed through a column of the anion exchange resin (Dowex™ Marathon WBA) phosphate was separated perfectly from arsenic(V). The silicate was separated by adding 2 mmol/L of sodium fluoride (NaF) as a masking agent. The effects of other competing ions such as Sb 3+ , Cr 3+ , Co 2+ , Ni 2+ , Mg 2+ , Ca 2+ , Zn 2+ , Pb 2+ , Cd 2+ , Fe 3+ , Al 3+ , SO4 2- , F - , Cl - and NO3 - were also evaluated. The date clarified that the existence of these ions did not cause any significant interference.
Secondly, the interference was carried out in the case of phosphate determination.
Arsenic(V) was tolerated up to 5.0 mg/L in the case of using sodium dithionite as a masking agent. Silicate was tolerated up to 5.0 mg/L when using oxalic acid as a masking agent. Other competing ions such as Sb 3+ , Cr 3+ , Co 2+ , Ni 2+ , Mg 2+ , Ca 2+ , Zn 2+ , Pb 2+ , Cd 2+ , Fe 3+ , Al 3+ , NO 3- , SO4 2- , F - , Cl - and NO3 - did not show any significant change in the absorbance compared with the blank samples even at high concentration up to 100 mg/L (Table 4).

sections.heading: 3.4. Reusability of the nano-conjugate materials
sections.text:
Since the nano-conjugate materials can hardly react with arsenic(V) and phosphate ions in
alkaline conditions (Fig. 4A), it is expected that the used nano-conjugate materials could be regenerated by a sodium hydroxide solution. It was found that arsenic(V) and phosphate were
successfully eluted upon treatment of the colored nano-conjugate material with 0.2 M NaOH. As the recovery times increased, the adsorption capability of arsenic(V) and phosphate decreased (Table 2).

sections.heading: 3.5. Digital Image-Based Colorimetric Analysis (DIC)
sections.text:
Digital images of the colored nano-conjugate material were analyzed utilizing Adobe
Photoshop CS5. Table 1 shows the digital images for the nano-conjugate material with different concentrations of arsenic(V) and phosphate ions. The images were shown a variation in color intensity relative to ion concentrations. When the concentration of analyte ions was increased, the most intense color was produced, and the mean integer value for each RGB component decreased. The intensity of the red component of the nano-conjugate materials was decreased with increasing concentrations of the arsenic(V) and phosphate ions, the intensities associated with the blue and the green components remain practically unchanged or minimally decreased in comparison to the red one (Fig. 7). Red is the complementary color of blue, and thus a high absorbance of this color was expected given the hypothetical test color was blue.
In an attempt to develop a similar calibration curve to that obtained from
spectrophotometry (Fig. 6), the color intensity to the absorbance at each concentration was correlated, utilizing the following equation:
(3)
where each color X: (R, B, G), AX is the absorbance of X, IX and RX are the intensity
and the reflectance of light X, respectively, IX,b= 0, IX,w= 255, and C is the concentration of X [58]. As shown in Fig. 8, the relations between AX and the concentrations of arsenic(V) and phosphate ions are similar and agreed with the previous correlations presented in Fig. 6.
The linear correlation between the absorbance of the mean integer value for each
RGB component and the concentration of arsenic(V) and phosphate ions (Fig. 8), the data confirmed that these ions was detected with high sensitivity at very low concentrations. These curves showed that the limit of detection (LOD) and quantification (LOQ) limits of these ions were using the nano-conjugate materials did not differ much from those obtained by the spectrophotometric method (Table 4). Therefore, the digitally scanned images appear competitive for the quantification of the metal ions.

sections.heading: 3.6. Adsorption capacity
sections.text:
The adsorption capacity is an important factor to know how much of sorbent is required
for the quantitative enrichment of an analyte in a given solution. In order to evaluate the adsorption capacity of the nano-conjugate materials, a batch method was utilized in which 50 mL of 50 mg/L of each arsenic(V) and phosphate solutions at pH 2.0 and 1.5, respectively; where the nano-conjugate materials was 10 mg. The mixture was filtered, and the retained arsenic(V) or phosphate in supernatant solution determined by ICP-AES. The capacity of the sorbent was 82.4 and 70.47 mg/g of arsenic(V) and phosphate per gram of nano-conjugate materials, respectively.
The effect of the different concentrations of arsenic(V) and phosphate on the adsorption
capacity was also evaluated (Fig. 9). Arsenic(V) or phosphate coverage onto the nanoconjugate materials at constant temperature is depicted by the Langmuir isotherm according to the following equation [59]:
Ce/qe = Ce/qm + 1/KLqm (4)
where Ce is the concentration of the arsenic(V) or phosphate in solution at equilibrium
(mg/L), qe is the amount of arsenic(V) or phosphate adsorbed on the nano-conjugate materials at equilibrium (mg/g), qm is the amount of arsenic(V) or phosphate adsorbed to form a
monolayer coverage (mg/g), and KL is the Langmuir adsorption equilibrium constant. The results indicated that the equilibrium adsorption capacity was increased with increasing concentration of arsenic(V) or phosphate. The straight line of the Ce/qe versus Ce plot of this adsorption test indicated the formation of the monolayer coverage of arsenic(V) or phosphate on the surface of the nano-conjugate materials (Fig. 9 insert). The practical adsorption capacity (qm) and the Langmuir coverage constant (KL) were obtained from the slope and intercept of the linear regions of the Langmuir plots, respectively. The linear adsorption curves indicated that a wide range of concentrations of arsenic(V) or phosphate was extracted. A linear graph with a correlation coefficient of 0.996 shows that the Langmuir adsorption isotherms characterize the adsorption tests towards arsenic(V) or phosphate.

sections.heading: 3.7. Application
sections.text:
For environmental applications, the performance of the nano-conjugate material depends on its ability to detect the target ion of interest in real water samples. In order to evaluate the nano-conjugate material efficiency for detection of arsenic(V) and phosphate, the nanoconjugate materials was tested in real water samples containing different ions which may cause interference with the arsenic(V) or phosphate. Water samples containing phosphate were collected from Attaka Power Station in Suez Gulf region, Egypt (high-pressure boiler samples) to test the performance of the nano-conjugate materials. The samples were diluted (1:4) without any further treatments. Nano-conjugate materials were added to the samples following the general procedure described in the preceding experimental section. Phosphate was detected by naked eye and determined by UV-Vis spectroscopy.
In order to test the ability of nano-conjugate materials for arsenic(V) detection, water
samples were collected from underground water in Wadi El Natroan, Egypt. The collected sample was tested directly without any treatments and nano-conjugate material was added to
the samples according to the general procedure as described in the preceding section. Arsenic(V) was detected by naked eye and determined by UV-Vis spectroscopy.
The results of the real water samples analyzed by the new nano-conjugate materials were found to be in good agreement with those obtained by ICP-AES [60] with a confidence level of 95% (3% RSD) (Table 6).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this work, the fabrication of nano-conjugate material was investigated for sensitive
detection and removal of arsenic(V) and phosphate in water samples. The nano-conjugate material was generated color changes, which were detected visually without using of sophisticated instruments. The nano-conjugate material was proposed as a simple, rapid, sensitive method for simultaneous arsenic(V) and phosphate detection and removal from water. The material could capture the ultra-trace arsenic(V) and phosphate via a colorimetric signal response with naked-eye observation. The detection limit was 0.15 and 0.13 μg/L for arsenic(V) and phosphate, respectively, which give the prepared nano-conjugate material the advantage of determination of arsenic(V) in drinking water and phosphate in industrial samples. The determined maximum adsorption capacity of arsenic(V) and phosphate was 82.40 and 70.47 mg/g, respectively. The presence of diverse ions did not affect the arsenic(V) or phosphate sensing, and adsorption operation by the nano-conjugate material could adsorb from multi-mixture solutions or industrial samples with high selectivity. The adsorbed arsenic(V) or phosphate were eluted with 0.20 M NaOH, and the materials were simultaneously regenerated into the initial form for the next arsenic(V) or phosphate capturing system after rinsing with water. Then the nano-conjugate material allows simple, rapid and low-cost detection and removal of trace arsenic(V) and phosphate in aqueous media.

metadata.abstractText: In this study, the ligand functionalized nano-conjugate material was developed for the sensitive and selective detection and removal of toxic arsenic(V) and phosphate ions in aqueous media. The nano-conjugate material was fabricated based on the use of metalorganic frameworks with exhibited of high surface area, pore morphology, and tuneable shape. The newly design nano-conjugate material was exhibited the naked eye monitoring of the ultra-trace arsenic(V) and phosphate in a simple, fast, cost-effective and easy-to-use approach. The data clarified that the arsenic(V) and phosphate adsorption process were found to be relatively fast. The adsorption isotherms of arsenic(V) and phosphate from aqueous solutions to the nano-conjugate material were measured, and the results showed that the Langmuir isotherm was found to be the best represent the measured adsorption data. The maximum adsorption capacity was 82.40 and 70.47 mg/g for arsenic(V) and phosphate, respectively. The arsenic(V) and phosphate detection and removal were not affected in the presence of co-existing divers ions. Calibration curves were demonstrated by using UV-Vis spectrophotometric and digital image-based colorimetric analysis. The linear correlation obtained from the two methods, and the detection limit of arsenic(V) and phosphate were 0.15 and 0.13 μg/L, respectively. In addition, the nano-conjugate material was regenerated by 0.20 M NaOH treatment the arsenic(V) and phosphate detection or removal efficiency was retained almost as that of the original performance. In addition, the nano-conjugate material was applied to the determination and removal of arsenic(V) and phosphate in natural and industrial water samples. Therefore, the newly developed nanomaterial has potentiality for efficient detection and removal of arsenic(V) and phosphate in the real wastewater samples.
